title: Release v4.1.0 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
Mastodon v4.1.0 got released today!
Some awesome additions that people have been after for a while now:
- Add support for importing/exporting server-wide domain blocks
- Ensure exact match is the first result in hashtag searches
- Add support for editing media description and focus point of already-sent posts
- Add listing of followed hashtags

And the list of fixes inbound with this version is monstrous.

This is great to see, but please keep in mind that your particular instance will need to be updated to this version so not all instances will update at the same time.

Some apps may also need to be updated in order to support these new features.

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v4.1.0

#Mastodon #Update #MastodonTips #FediTips

title: umbrella/npm-stats.ts at develop · thi-ng/umbrella

last_post.content:
WOW!! 🤯 Earlier this evening I kicked off (throttled) queries to ask the NPM API for download stats of all 177 #ThingUmbrella packages. Since 2018, in total they have been downloaded a whopping:

44,811,420 times!

This number is so *mindblowing* to me, since it's such a truly weird and insane contrast to the general level of feedback, contributions & attention received...

(And to imagine, if each d/l would provide even just €0.01 in return...)

It's also very interesting to learn from that which are the most & least downloaded packages, some completely against any of my own hunches/predictions and/or what I'd consider essential packages... The by far least popular projects are all related to #WebAssembly interop, each of which only had 1-4k downloads so far. Didn't expect those to be so niche...

In case anyone is interested, the stats collector is here:

https://github.com/thi-ng/umbrella/blob/develop/tools/src/npm-stats.ts

#OpenSource

title: https://github.com/yonicd/covr

last_post.content:
Alrighty I feel like I've run into this #rstats #unittesting issue many times, and each time I get confused.

In testthat - I want to be able to keep a log of the tests somewhere so I can look at date/timestamped tests.

I remember that there's something about special "Reporter" classes or something, but I don't really know what that means, and I can't seem to find examples on the testthat documentation. I could definitely be missing something here - if anyone knows were to look, I'm all ears.

My question is:

How do I save the text output from `testthat::test()`?

I seem to recall that there's some testthat option, but I can't seem to find it here: https://testthat.r-lib.org/reference/index.html#reporters

I also can't seem to find much info about Reporters here? https://testthat.r-lib.org/reference/MinimalReporter.html I see that they are mentioned in NEWS: https://testthat.r-lib.org/news/index.html?q=reporter#reporters-1-0-0

Anywho, my usecase is this:

My tests sometimes 15-20 minutes. I want to check that I'm getting consistent testing behaviour, but after tinkering and fixing, I can't see what the original test failures were. So I need to run them again, and that takes time.

Yes, I can check GH actions tests, but sometimes those aren't accurate for GH related reasons.

Has anyone got some thoughts on this?

I should also note that @yoni_cd 's https://github.com/yonicd/covr package does nearly everything I want, however I have run into some minor issues to do with my pkg that break things.

title: https://gitlab.com/Eidonko/veemadge

last_post.content:
What is the greatest unknown, if not the universe itself? It seemed natural, therefore, to chose an image of the universe as the source for the new video of "Unknow", a piece for piano, bass, contrabass, electronic drums, and oud, dedicated to the homonym character by Magnus (Roberto Raviola). You can freely download the song in lossless format from https://eidon.bandcamp.com/track/unknow

"Unknow" is one of my "imaginary soundtracks" -- soundtracks for movies, or cartoons, which actually... do not exist (yet). Here I try to represent the strain of a life in perennial flight from the perils of the present and the horror of the past. The "fugato" in the piece corresponds to this flight -- this fugue state, if you allow me the pun.

If you like this piece, follow me on Bandcamp: https://eidon.bandcamp.com/follow_me on youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCZ0UIBDZEYlvn8thxv3aOxw, and FB, https://www.facebook.com/EidonVeda.

Video is a zoom out of "Tapestry of Blazing Starbirth" (https://esahubble.org/images/heic2007a/), a NASA/ESA/Hubble picture. Credit: NASA, ESA, and STScI. License: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/
The video consists of portions of the original image, scaled down to a frame size of 900x618 pixels.

The video was created with veemadge (https://gitlab.com/Eidonko/veemadge). It can be watche also on #youtube: https://youtu.be/Bq0nEhlJoME.

The music is by and (c) Eidon (Eidon at tutanota.com, Eidon.Songs at gmail.com). All rights reserved.

title: Making SQLite extensions pip install-able

last_post.content:
Ferociously useful work here from @alexgarciaxyz: https://observablehq.com/@asg017/making-sqlite-extensions-pip-install-able

Alex figured out how to bundle compiled SQLite extensions in per-platform Python wheels and ship them to PyPI - so now you can do things like "pip install sqlite-regex" to get his SQLite regex functions, which he implemented in Rust

More notes here: https://simonwillison.net/2023/Feb/6/making-sqlite-extensions-pip-install-able/

title: https://github.com/bigcode-project

last_post.content:
Probably the most convoluted of the weekend :

using BigCodeProject SantaCoder🎅🤗 to generate a function, evaluating it within the global scope eval?.() then making it available as a manipulable and executable by hand.👌

Coding in #WebXR yes, but with #AI assist!🤖

See https://huggingface.co/spaces/bigcode/santacoder-demo by Loubna Ben Allal and others👍

Why I care for that more than more popular projects? I could introspect the entire stack. https://huggingface.co/datasets/bigcode/the-stack and https://github.com/bigcode-project It doesn't mean I can or will but just knowing it's a possibility changes everything. No black box.

title: GitHub - kdeldycke/awesome-falsehood: 😱 Falsehoods Programmers Believe in

last_post.content:
“This is a recurring form of techno-hubris: the idea that baseline concepts like "family" have crisp definitions and that any exceptions are outliers that would never swallow the rule. It's such a common misstep that there's a whole genre called "Falsehoods Programmers Believe About ______": https://github.com/kdeldycke/awesome-falsehood In that list: names, time, currency, birthdays, timezones, email addresses, national borders, nations, biometrics, gender, language, alphabets, phone numbers, addresses, systems of measurement, and, of course, families.” —@pluralistic via https://pluralistic.net/2023/02/02/nonbinary-families/

I didn’t know this genre was so packed.

title: https://github.com/divamgupta/diffusionbee-stable-diffusion-ui

last_post.content:
There are several macOS #StableDiffusion GUIs (besides the web GUIs) out there:

1. Diffusion Bee: https://github.com/divamgupta/diffusionbee-stable-diffusion-ui — the grand-daddy of them all since it has been around since the early days.

2. Swift CoreML Diffusers: https://github.com/huggingface/swift-coreml-diffusers — the original CoreML GUI from HuggingFace which started out a new bunch of UIs.

3. MochiDiffusion: https://github.com/godly-devotion/MochiDiffusion — based on the codebase for #2 but now seems to be hard-forked.

4. Ink Bot: https://testflight.apple.com/join/40gExWSM — No website for the app, only the TestFlight page and some info on Mastodon.

I’ve tried all of the above and have even done my own fork of #2 and added my own features: https://github.com/FahimF/swift-coreml-diffusers/

But of the lot, I think I like Ink Bot the best … provided it had a few more features/tweaks. Unfortunately, since it’s closed source, I can’t modify the code to add the features I want 😛

So either I have to go back to my fork of the HuggingFace UI, or start with one of the other options and add the features I want. But I’m still working on my fork of Tusker (Fediverse client in case the sudden segue is confusing …) to add the features I want there … And I want the weekend for reading/writing.

What do do? I don’t know … The urge to code is hard 😜

No clue when it'll go live but that's pretty cool for an old guy used to 2 week+ to never turn around times.
